In my opinion both of those older cameras produced better quality pictures than this state-of-the-art megazoom camera.  Maybe it's unfair to expect this to perform as well as even a relatively cheap DSLR (although other reviewers here have done so), but it should have been way better than my old Coolpix P4.I have to say the zoom range on this camera was incredible.  I also liked the flexibility from full-auto to fully manual.  This would have been perfect for an SLR guy like me.  The touch screen on the back is borderline useless, but that's easy to ignore. Picture quality on the other hand?  I can't ignore that at this price point.  I'm back to the drawing board, and again researching other point-and-shoot cameras.

Reviews.Title: Small camera w/big zoom
Reviews.Author: D. Rife "Rifester"
Reviews.Content: I previously owned the Lumix DMC-TZ5. I think I have had it for about 5 years now and I have a lot of really good pictures from it. The screen just recently cracked in the corner and turned black, but it still works well. I bought the Sony DSC-HX9V because Cnet gave it such a good review, but I took it back because I didn't like the pictures. They looked too soft or more like a water color painting to me. I was waiting for a new and better camera that was pocket size, but with long zoom. I bought the ZS20 because it has everything I wanted plus some. The things that I wanted most were the long zoom, HD video, and good picture quality. It has that and more. The other things that are nice is that it has high speed video, panoramic, GPS, face recognition, and speedy auto focus. It also has a touch screen which I personally like. I like it because you don't have to use the touch screen for everything, only for a few of the controls. You can touch a person or object on the screen and it will focus and take a picture. The other thing is that if you use the zoom on the screen it will zoom all the way to 20x automatically. If you want to zoom in slow or only half way than you can use the finger zoom in front of the shutter button. You can also turn off the touch on the screen if you don't want to use it.  I actually haven't taken very many pictures with it yet, but so far it is nice. One thing I have noticed though is when you take a picture in low light the lens sticks out so far that the flash creates a shadow in the bottom left corner of the picture because the lens is in the way. That is miner to me though because I would rather have the long lens then not. I have used the video on the camera about three times now and it seems to me that sometimes the video will speed up slightly when it is played back on my computer. I am going to keep using it, but if it does it on every video I might have a defective camera. The GPS also uses the battery up fast. The battery charges in the camera now which would be nice while I am traveling, but it sucks at home because you can't use the camera and charge it at the same time. The camera has to be off to charge. The first day I got it the battery died really fast because it wasn't charged all the way so I had to let it charge up before I could start playing with it again. I definitely need to get more batteries and a wall charger. I like the GPS though. I turn it off when I am taking pictures around the house, but when I use it everywhere else I like to have the GPS on so I can see on Google Earth the exact spot I took the picture. If you download Picasa and Google Earth. It will show you right where you took the picture on a Google earth map, and I can see other pictures people have taken and shared. So far this camera is pretty nice and it is a keeper. The only thing that really sucks is that by the time I got the camera with 2 day shipping the camera was already $40 dollars cheaper.UPDATE: Has anyone else had a problem with the video speeding up for a second here and there? I'm sending mine back because mine does. FYI Amazon sent me a broken camera so i sent it back for a refund and they charged me an Item Promotion Deduction*: ($8.79). Not ever buying electronics online because if you ever have any problems with them it is a pain.26JULY2012: The high speed video on this camera sucks. It is less that standard video quality. I couldn't wait to use this feature, but it is almost useless in my opinion.

Reviews.Title: Tried two cameras both were bad
Reviews.Author: Eric
Reviews.Content: Panasonic has a quality issue with these cameras.  I ordered one after seeing a good overall review score.  I had hoped to get a good unit.  The first unit came and no matter what I did I could not get a nice clear picture.  I tried all kinds of settings as suggested in different reviews here.  So I gave up and set it back for a replacement.  When the replacement showed I took a quick set of pictures.  Low and behold the first shot was much cleaner.  I was happy... but... only the first shot.  Once again it took all lousy pictures.  I even took it to a family member who has a DSLR and knows all the proper setting for lighting and such.  He could not get this second unit to take a clear picture.  So... on last chance.  My wife purchased a Fuji Film camera (dont have model # handy) and I took side by side shots of them both in Auto mode.  What a difference... the Fuji was taking pictures as I would expect a $300 camera to take.  There was no comparison.  I would avoid the Panasonic unless you like to keep sending them back until you get a good one.  I wanted to love it... but hated it.

Reviews.Title: Best of the Zs series .
Reviews.Author: Reel To Real
Reviews.Content: Okay, I like the Panasonic's Zs cameras. They're easy to get the hang of and I've had no reliability issues. I started with a Panasonic Zs3. Later on I upgraded to a Zs7, then when I saw Amazon was selling a Zs9 which was the same as the Zs8 but with a stereo microphone and the price wasn't much over $100 (from Amazon Warehouse), I couldn't resist buying it for its 16x zoom. It's been a great camera. I love my Zs9 with it's long zoom despite it not having GPS (which I didn't care about) or HDMI out, and with a lower LCD screen resolution than the Zs7. I thought the screen clarity was fine and didn't miss the 460,000 dots on the Zs7.Well, I couldn't resist this newer upgraded Zs. The Zs20 is my 4th Panasonic Lumix Zs camera (all of them purchased from Amazon), and I can say without reservation that this is the best of them all. I love the fast burst shooting made possible by the CMOS sensor.The 16x zoom on the Zs8/9 is really great. I've taken some fantastic close-up shots with it. Now I have a 20x zoom. Amazing. It's operates when shooting video too.Canon's G series, by comparison, has a larger 1:1.7 sensor compared to the Zs20 1:2.33. But, the zoom is very limited on the Canon and the camera is too big to carry around in your pocket - and it cost twice as much (and the older unavailable G9 model is better than the later ones I hear.) Their competitor for this Panasonic is their 20x zoom model SX260SH with a similar 1:2.33 CMOS sensor. Professional reviewers are rating the Zs20 higher than the comparable Canon, which is slightly larger, heavier, and costs more. Everyone raves about Panasonic's Leica lenses, with good reason. The Zs20 is just an amazing camera for the price. It's even slightly smaller than the Zs 7,8/9/10 and easy to carry in your pocket in a thin stretch case. Like the Zs7 (which never cost less than about $250.00) it has the 460,000 dot bright LCD screen, HDMI out, and GPS. It also has more features than the Zs7 or 8/9/10.Don't expect the price to get much lower. As I recall, the Zs10 (the real predecessor of the Zs20) price came down to about the Zs20 price today, or maybe at the very end, a few dollars less, but I wouldn't wait. Panasonic may refuse to lower the price any further. It's already so heavily discounted, and there is a limit to how low they'll go. If you want the absolute best deal, get a "used" one from Amazon Warehouse. It's hardly, if at all "used," and most likely brand new but returned for some reason and re-packaged. You have 30 days to send it back if there is anything wrong with it. You don't get the one year warranty however, so if that's important to you, but a new one. It's definitely worth the price. I already had an extra battery but you can buy a non-proprietary battery very inexpensively that lasts even longer than the battery that comes with the camera. I also had a wall charger (two - from my Zs7 and Zs9)), so I didn't have to buy that. I'd say that's the only thing Panasonic let down on. It's worth getting a wall charger, but it should come with the camera. This is the first time it doesn't. Don't let it deter you.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera, a great replacement for the ZS7
Reviews.Author: Sam Smith
Reviews.Content: We previously owned a Lumix ZS7 and was extremely happy with the camera. It took great pictures, particularly outdoors which is where we take most of our pictures. Sadly it broke (dropped it), so we needed a replacement. Whatever camera we were going to buy to replace the ZS7 had some very big shoes to fill, and we were convinced no camera would match it's quality given the type of camera and price range we were looking. We ended up buying the ZS20 as a replacement for the broken ZS7 and it has not disappointed at all. In fact, the pictures are richer, sharper and overall just much better than the ZS7. It's also a little bit smaller in size, enough to notice the difference.Overall we are VERY pleased with this camera.  All of our friends with an average point-n-shoot digital don't even bother bringing their camera when we go on camping and hiking trips because they just want copies of our pictures from the ZS20. This camera makes me look like a semi-professional photographer.My only complaint so far is I'm not a huge fan of the touch screen (it works so-so). I just use the buttons, but on occasion I like to point to something on the screen, or I occasionally just hit it with my clumsy fingers, and it does something unintentional like take a close-up picture of my nose hairs. I also wish it came with an external charger like the ZS7 so you can charge one battery while using another in the camera. Luckily I still have the old external charger from the ZS7 so it's not a problem for me, but it would be for most everyone else.

Reviews.Title: great pictures at highest zoom and range
Reviews.Author: bigronbo
Reviews.Content: I went to a hotel by an outdoor auditorium. My friend had tickets to the concert and a room for us to watch from. We were 17 stories up and totally outside and behind the arena I was shooting with full 40x zoom through double pane glass that was dirty on both sides hand held/ no tripod and got amazingly close pictures that had the people so close that they filled the picture. The zoom and stabilization are amazing. I found that I need to set custom settings to shoot that far at full zoom to get better pictures with no blur for moving targets. The shutter speed needs to be higher than the normal scene shot of through glass has. It was totally dark outside also. The pictures that they were not moving fast were really impressive. I can't wait for the Sept 20 band 2 day event we have. I do need batteries they don't last that long. I got 194 pictures and 3 videos of about one min each. Still had one bar so could have had more. Read the reviews on line and you will see for the features and cost there are none better.

Reviews.Title: Very impressed at what this little camera can do
Reviews.Author: AZ buyer "AZ buyer"
Reviews.Content: I am very impressed at what this little camera can do. I have taken many panorama shots, with people included, and as long as the people are not moving quickly, just standing & talking, it does well. If a person is moving quickly, they will not turn out well.Places with the panorama shots has been very good.The ability to repeatedly shoot in a dark location with a flash is excellent.The burst shots are great... I use the auto focus shots the most, but will use the other one if the time between the shots is needed.The clarity is good for a little camera.GPS, I've still not been able to make it work on either camera...could be operator error.Zoom is good.Many good options, with clear pictures for a small camera.Am impressed. Purchased one for a family member who wants to shot basic shots with a small camera versus a large one that ranges closer to the prosumer versions.I am particular about what is within limits of quality, even with the smaller camera (or phone), so I checked it out first before giving it to them. I liked it so well, I got my own also.I do recommend it. Enough so that when I showed it to a cousin who is a photographer, he was impressed with its ability as well being such a small camera.

Reviews.Title: Small Camera with Great Zoom but Poor Pic Quality, A bad Copy?
Reviews.Author: Tony T. Kao "Holycow"
Reviews.Content: My Boss lady bought this camera as soon as it was available couple weeks ago.  The same day she got it she decided to return the camera.  She complained the picture qualities were not as sharp as her other older compact cameras.  I asked her to try a couple days and get use to the way the camera take pictures.  She brought to work and we tried different settings(ISO, Iauto, P, S, A,...etc) and shooting conditions indoor, outdoor, macro, zoom(mid to long).  I had to agree, for some reason the ZS20 is not taking as sharp picture as my dad's ZS7 or my Panasonic LX5.  I know it's comparing to orange to an apple when it is compare to LX5 but it's hard to keep the camera when the only decent pictures we got were macro shots.  Everything else was too pixelated on my 24in monitor even the ones with ample daylight. She end up taking her Canon T2i and Olympus EPL1 with her on family trip and returned the ZS20.The camera is amazingly small(with the mega zoom lens it is even a bit smaller than my LX5, but this can also be a problem if you have a big hand....) and zoom is great if you do not care the pictures are not going to be sharp.  We don't know if we had a bad copy or not but my boss lady doesn't want to spend more shipping cost to find out~The buttons and menus on the ZS20 is very similar to other Panasonic compact camera families(at least compare to older ZS and LX5).  So if you had an older Panasonic, learning curve on this camera is very fast.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous Upgrade From Prior TZ3 Model
Reviews.Author: Just Another Geek "vikast"
Reviews.Content: The ZS20 is also called the TZ30 in other parts of the world.  The TZ stands for Travel Zoom and this camera continues the great tradition of having a great compact camera for travelling.  I purchased the Panasonic Lumix TZ3 in 2007 and felt that I needed an upgrade to catch up with technology.  The TZ30 has double the zoom, panoroma mode, HD video recording, touch screen and significantly faster performance than the TZ3.  Given technology commoditization, I paid less for the TZ30 than I did for the TZ3 five years. ago.Pros:Compact size - The TZ30 is actually smaller than my old TZ3 and is comporable or smaller than many of its competition.  The camera still isn't pants-pocketable, but fit very well in cargo pockets or jacket pockets.Image Quality - Outdoor pictures are great.  Indoor pictures are actually very good, particularly when using a flash.  Several reviewers have complained about poor indoor picture quality, particularly noise at higher ISOs.  Certainly, the Lumix does not match DSLR or professional quality point and shoot cameras with large apertures, but I don't really notice an issue as a casual user.  I was taking pictures inside Las Vegas casinos and the pictures were fine.  I also created a panorama picture on the Vegas strip at night, with no issues.  Publishing on facebook or printing smaller photos (e.g., up to 8x10) won't raise any issues (in fact Facebook introduces more noise using their compression algorithms than any noise in the source picture)Zoom - 20x optical zoom rocks.  The TZ3 had a 10x zoom and I thought that was pretty useful, but the 20x allows a whole new level of capturing images.  Not only is the zoom at the telephoto end pretty good, but Panasonic has made the wide angle lense a bit wider for capturing scenery or group photosPanorama Mode - Panasonic probably stole this from Sony, but you can take a panorama picture by sweeping the camera from side to side.  The camera then stitches together a composite panoramic picture.  Note, that the lense has to be at wide angle in order to use the panorama.  Moreover, one's sweeping movements may cause some unusual distortion of the picture (where the center gets curved).Video - The camera provides 1080P video capture (full HD) and can capture in MP4 or AVCHD formats. I tend to use MP4, since it is easier to edit. Unlike my old TZ3, I can actually zoom and record.  There is some sound from the zoom lense if you change zoom and record, but not terrible.  You can also capture still pictures at 3 or 4MP while recording.Speed - The camera is quite quick.  The camera turns on quickly and shutter lag is minimal.  Auto focus is very quick and can actually track an object (great for kids or animals).Travel Features - The Travel Zoom series is targetted at travellers and the camera continues to have the appropriate features, including GPS, world travel clock, using the tele/wide toggle switch to find pictures on a calendar, etc.Cons:1. GPS - Although a great feature, I spend most of the time with it turned off in order to reduce battery drain.  I think the GPS will be nice when I'm travelling to foreign lands, but I don't think it is all that useful in daily use.2. Charging System - One has to charge the camera by plugging a USB cord into the camera.  As a result, it takes quite a while to fully charge the camera. There is an optional charger that is available, which will allow charging a battery while using your camera and much faster charging times, so plan on a few bucks to purchase the external charger. Battery usage on the camera is fine.  I took ~70 pictures with flash in Las Vegas (but GPS off) and barely dented the battery capacity.  I anticipate a couple of hundred pictures before the battery discharges.3. Record / Playback Switch - The switch easily gets moved between the two settings. Just wish it was a little more robust.  Product build otherwise is pretty god.So why purchase the Panasonic instead of competing cameras from Sony, Canon or Nikon?  When I was looking at similar cameras, I found the Panasonic to be slightly more competitively priced, while providing a more robust feature set.  Moreover, my experience with the TZ3 suggests great build quality, which allows the camera to stand up to global travel.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera with a fantastic zoom
Reviews.Author: TJ
Reviews.Content: So far I am very happy with the performance of my Lumix ZS 20 Camera.Overall a great capable camera at this price range.Pros:1. Excellent zoom2. Very sharp & crisp audio & video quality3. GPS is a good feature for travelers like me4. Made in Japan Quality5. Cool panoramic shotsCons.1. Average photo quality in low lighting condition.2. The on-off button could have scope for improvement , sometime accidentally it gets switched on.3. Non standard mini USB cable is a big NO...4. Touch screen sometimes lets you down5. Takes a while to charge the in-camera battery, not very happy about the battery life.

Reviews.Title: Big Disappointment
Reviews.Author: johngalt
Reviews.Content: This is my second Lumix after having Canons.  I had a ZS3 with 12X optical zoom.  I absolutely loved that camera (a friend dropped it).  I took a picture once on full zoom out of a plane window of a ship in the water below at least 2 miles away.  It was just a speck in the distance.  I then magnified the image on the camera's screen and I could see the color of the ship, how many stacks it had, etc.  It was simply amazing.  Well, I bought this thinking that the 20X zoom would be even better.  It was not, and actually it is nowhere close to the ZS3.  There is something wrong with the focus.  When you zoom on the screen the picture is fuzzy.  I took the same picture with the Z20 and an older Canon. The old Cannon looked much better. This camera may be too technically ambitious.  It has some nice features but they went way over the top and made a mess in the process.I also went to Costco and checked out the Z19 -- it seemed to be better, although I had to take a picture in the store and I didn't have a direct comparison.I read some other reviews here saying that someone else had the same problem and that Panasonic was updating the firmware.  But I called Panasonic twice and they have no firmware update planned and the reps said they know of no such problem. The firmware on the camera is version 1.0.  I told them about the reviews on Amazon and they clearly didn't want to know anything about it.I can't live with fuzzy pictures so this camera is going back to Amazon.  Buyer beware.UPDATE----I have since gone back to Costco to check out the zs-19 and looked at it more carefully.  The fuzziness was no better than the ZS-20.  So I ended up replacing my original ZS-3 with a factory refurbished unit I found online.  It will get me through until Panasonic fixes their issues.  What was also interesting was that several sources online sell the ZS-3 new for $4-500 even though it's an old model. The lens was really great on the ZS3.  The later ZS models use some lens tricks to try and get the same results using less lens -- this could be an issue.

Reviews.Title: I like it, but has it's flaws.
Reviews.Author: T Post
Reviews.Content: At this time there are seveal hundred reviews so I won't re-hash the specs as others have done a nice job. Overall I like this camera, but there are 2 things that caused me to rate it a 3 star:- Low light quality isn't anything to jump at, I previously had a $100 Nikon and Cannon and would rate the quality equal; this camera doesn't stand out a for picture quality. It isn't bad quality, but the same as you might find in a lower end different brand model.- You have to switch a button to toggle between taking pictures and reviewing pictures. At the surface this sounds trivial, but after a few months use I find it annoying. Each time you toggle the lens retracts and there is a few second delay. This becomes annoying if you take a picture and want to have a quick look at it before snapping another. You have to retract the lens, find the picture then expand the lens again before you can take another picture. Seems most other brands let you preview quickly while taking pictures, I am just not happy with the extra time it takes with this model.

Reviews.Title: ZS20 and ZS15 comparison
Reviews.Author: Ashlea Beers
Reviews.Content: I purchased both the ZS20 and ZS15 to compare the two cameras and decide which one I like better. Since the ZS15 was significantly less expensive than the ZS20, I decided it was worth trying both. As far as I can tell, the technical differences between the two are A) 20x optical zoom vs 15x optical zoom, B) 14.1 MP vs 12.1 MP, and C) the ZS20 has GPS but the ZS15 does not.As most casual, yet technically savvy, photographers already know, the 2 MP is not going to make a huge difference at this level for day-to-day picture taking. As for me, this camera is to take pictures of family (usually kids) and of nature/wildlife. We live in Colorado and spend a lot of time in the mountains taking pictures of the scenery and wildlife, so a good optical zoom was very important for me. I've never blown up a non-professional picture bigger than 11x14, so the megapixel difference was a wash for me. Another big requirement I have is decent picture taking in low light. It's not like I'm trying to take pictures inside, at night, with the lights off - but it would be nice to take pictures in a room with dim lighting without the flash making everything look funky or getting picture after picture with people's eyes closed.Out of the box, I started taking pictures with both the iA mode and various different "scene" modes. Honestly, on both cameras, I found most scenarios to have the same experience and quality. However, with taking pictures in EXTREMELY low light (with a light on behind me but no lighting in the room of the subject I was taking a picture of) were quite different between the two cameras. It seems that the less light in the room, the longer it would be for the camera to take the picture after pressing down on the button. There was a much longer delay on the ZS20 in this circumstance, and it was extremely frustrating. At first, I even thought I wasn't pressing the button down, but I was. The ZS15 still had a delay, but not quite as long as the ZS20. I tried this in both iA and multiple scene modes and had the same result. Again, this was extreme, as I was doing it in a room with almost no light - I could not even see what I was looking at through the LCD screen because it was so dark. I'm sure this can be corrected with manual settings, but I am not going to kid myself into thinking I'm going to learn the finer technical points of photography overnight. I couldn't tell any difference between the two cameras when it came to nighttime scenery with light (a dark street with streetlights) or natural daylight pictures.Sometimes I was very disappointed with the picture quality, but it was not the camera's fault. I know this because if I changed the settings, the same exact picture would look EXTREMELY different. If I didn't know any better, I would have thought the pictures were taken with two separate cameras. The reason I mention this is that I think this camera has fantastic potential. If you are willing to take the time to learn about cameras and the different settings to use in particular conditions, this will be an amazing camera. This is something I want to do, but I also wanted something that will take very good pictures out of the box using the default modes that are built in. If you are unable or unwilling to fiddle with changing to different presets and figuring out when to use those at the very least, I do not think this camera will be good for you. I am very excited to learn how to do the manual settings as I think this will take this camera to an even higher level. Again, the potential seems very high.As far as the zoom goes, the 16x vs 20x was something I was very curious about. Can I zoom in more on the 20x? Well, duh, of course I can! Enough to justify the cost difference? Eh, not so much. Optical zoom is very important to me, but 16x was more than enough to fulfill my needs. I just didn't think the extra zoom was worth it for me. The intelligent zoom is very good on both cameras to go beyond the optical zoom, which surprised me. I was able to take hand-held pictures at full zoom on both cameras without blur. Even taking pictures of a full moon on full zoom were quite impressive.The touch screen I didn't find particularly good. It's one of those that you kinda need to depress a little, which to me is not a sign of a very good or responsive touch screen. However, a touch screen on this camera that is similarly responsive as a high-end smartphone I think would cause a lot of accidental touches. So in this case, the touch screen is neither a plus nor a minus. I could go without it but it does not detract from it either.THE BOTTOM LINE:* Decent camera out of the box. It is definitely not a good choice for the older crowd or people who are not very technically inclined. If you can't program your DVR or set up a home wireless network (which to me are incredibly easy and basic things), then this is not for you. Stick with a Kodak EasyShare or a Canon PowerShot, which are more user-friendly from my experience.* Lots of potential with manual settings if you are willing to learn more than the average camera user to get the most out of your camera.* Optical zoom is fantastic for the camera size and price point.* Manual settings give this camera a significant advantage over similar cameras in this price range.Should you get the ZS20 or ZS15?I ultimately decided to keep the ZS15. I do not care about the GPS on the ZS20. For optical zoom, 16x already met my needs and I do not think the 4x extra zoom was worth the money. The 2 MP difference between the two cameras shouldn't matter for anyone that is specifically looking for this class of camera (an affordable, compact, point-and-shoot). If you really want the GPS or 4x more zoom, by all means get the more expensive camera - it just wasn't worth it for me. With the money I saved by sticking with the ZS15, I can get a new video game and a 12 pack of my favorite microbrew :)

Reviews.Title: So far so good...but one flaw that may be deal breaker
Reviews.Author: SDsportsFan
Reviews.Content: I haven't played around with this camera too much, however in the IA mode and taking photos indoors with moderate lighting have produced photos with the bottom left hand corner "shadow". No additional zoom. the built in flash isn't reaching the far left bottom corner. it's ruining all my indoor pictures that require flash. I'm not sure if this is a design flaw or just my camera. Now, i'm not sure i want to keep this camera as i do take a lot indoor photos. If anyone has a solution, please share!Outdoor photos turn out great! No shutter lag. Crisp photos. camera itself isn't too big nor too small. feels great in my hand.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!!!
Reviews.Author: dae06
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera now for about 6 months. I absolutely love it!! I previously bought a Fuji Finepix F70EXR and I really tried to get it to take decent pictures, but was unsuccessful. Then I read about the Lumix ZS20. It had very good reviews, but so did the Fuji. I decided to take the plunge and buy it. This is the best little camera I've owned so far. Great picture quality, easy to use, great zoom (one of things I look for a lot), no blurry picture problems at all like I had with the Fuji, and takes good pictures in low light. My wife it not too picky regarding sharp pictures, HD tv's etc., but she even said this is the best camera so far. I work in Radiology and deal with a lot of images day to day and can appreciate a good, high quality image so I know what I like and this camera gave me what I wanted.

Reviews.Title: Pleased so far.
Reviews.Author: Bob T.
Reviews.Content: I've only had this camera a few days, but so far I'm really happy with it.  The low-light sensitivity and optical zoom work as advertised.  The only complaint I have is that the on/off switch is located such that the camera can easily be inadvertently turned on when inserting it into a Case Logic case, or closing the zipper.  When that happens, the lens can start to expand against the inside of the case, possibly causing damage to it.  (I've already lost one camera this way.)  As a precaution, I always make sure the REC/PLAY switch is in the PLAY position when I stow the camera, so if it gets turned on, the lens will not expand.I recently dropped this camera in about an inch of salt water for a few seconds, and it completely shorted out.  It still overloads my USB port even though I've done everything I can do to dry it out.  Maybe I'll send it to the factory for repair.  Meanwhile, I like the camera so much that I've bought a replacement from Amazon.  I can't believe how fast the price keeps going up on this camera, so other people must like it too.-------------Now that I've had this camera for a few months, I still really like it, but I need to find a way to make it waterproof because there is so much water in this world that it's hard to avoid.

Reviews.Title: awesome camera
Reviews.Author: Sugarman
Reviews.Content: We ride motorcycle and my wife takes pics during all of our trips, even local ones. She wanted a camera that was faster than our Lumix ZS7. This camera is great. Because it is very similar to the ZS7 and takes the same battery, her learning curve was very short. The burst mode is great and allows us to get good shots that we would have missed. Not easy getting good pics at 70 mph from the back of the bike. We have taken over 10,000 pics in the last month without a glitch. (had to buy a 1TB hard drive to hold them) I would estimate that we get at least one good shot out of 95 percent of the burst shots. In normal shooting off the bike 99 percent of the shots are good because of the lack of delay when shooting. There are too many improvements to comment on but the best one is this camera with a case and extra battery and 16GB card was cheaper than the ZS7 alone. Can't beat that! She loves this camera. Also, we still use the ZS7 and never had a problem with it. Panasonic quality and reliability is top drawer.

Reviews.Title: Extremely Satisfied
Reviews.Author: rob-d
Reviews.Content: Update after about a year:  For a pocket camera, this is more than I had expected.  I didn't even bother bringing my larger Canon DSLR with us on vacation.  This camera took great videos and photos.  I'd still buy it again.  Old Review: I did quite a bit of research via amazon, newegg and other websites as well as visiting local retail stores.  What I found was that virtually all of the cameras had at least some negative reviews, usually related to a user getting a lemon.  It would appear that quality control is a bit of a problem for all of the major brands.  That being said, I wanted a camera that was small enough to easily fit into a pocket, a better than average zoom, could shoot panoramic shots, intuitive user interface and had better than average HD video.  This camera has not disappointed me in any way.  It has actually exceeded my expectations.  One of the reasons I purchased this camera is because of its GPS capabilities.  I must digress for a moment here.  I bought this as a present for my wife.  She had the patience to figure out how to use the GPS function.  I was amazed that once she had it set up, the location, including the special attraction we were at, scrolled across the bottom of the photo.  Awesome!!!!  There is one function for taking photos through glass which has been very useful when taking photos through the windshield of the car while moving.  It virtually removed all reflections.  The quality of the photos ( crispness and color) is excellent.  I was really surprised by the quality of the HD video that was taken inside in low light.  Although not perfect, it was definitely acceptable, considering the lighting level.  The sound quality was also acceptable, especially when considering that the primary function of the camera is still photos.  For the money, I think it is a great camera loaded with some unique features that many other cameras don't have.

Reviews.Title: Wow! finally a good successor to my ZS3 (and FZ50)!
Reviews.Author: Lackosleep "Lackosleep"
Reviews.Content: I've had many Panasonic Lumix series cameras, my two favorites being the compact ZS3 and the super zoom FZ50. I've tried to upgrade and replace them with newer models, because I love their excellant versatility and performance in a variety of shooting situations (ie, no need to cary a bag full of lenses and gadgets!#, and excellent image quality. But up until now, I couldn't find replacements that would offer both -- better performance/features AND better image qaulity consistently over the range of those differing shooting situations #wide/tele, sunlight/low light, macro/motion, etc). The FZ100 superzoom had a better feature set than the FZ50, but in my opinion worse image quality! And the ZS"everything after the 3" suffered either deficient performance, image quality or both. I tried several - the ZS7/8 and 10. But now I have the FZ150 superzoom and the ZS20 and they easily exceed the venerable FZ50 and ZS3 in feature set/performance AND meet or exceed them in image quality in across many shooting conditions! I've only had them a few days now, and have performed quiter a bit of informal, side-by-side testing and I am quite pleased by the image quality of the ZS20 and the FZ150. If you've been holding out for a replacement/upgrade of your older FZ or ZS series... wait no more! These two are sure to satisfy.-Lackosleep

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: J. McClarin
Reviews.Content: I have wanted a camera with an extended zoom for quite some time and have experimented over the past few months with a Nikon (24x zoom) and a Kodak camera (21x zoom).  I took the Nikon on my Vegas trip but unfortunately had a lot of blurry shots and the night shots were horrible (even with the night settings).  I returned that camera.  Earlier this year, I purchased a Kodak (practically dirt cheap now).  The camera does  take beautiful photos when it wants to.  I have never experienced such a long lag time between shots.  I was hard pressed to get good shots of animals at the zoo that were sitting still and heaven forbid if they moved.  I also used the Kodak during a trip to the lake and was extremely disappointed when I needed to take quick nature shots.  Waiting for this camera to "process" was excruciating!  After Vegas, I did learn to take a back-up camera so I used my old Panasonic (10x zoom) and I was able to catch many photos of birds in flight (including a bald eagle which was too cool).  I still have this camera (remember it was dirt cheap)!  Please note I am an amateur (or one level below) and all I know is that I love to take pictures (particularly macro floral shots).  I have had my new Panasonic camera for approximately 2 weeks and I have tried to use it in a variety of settings.  I have taken night shots, sports shots, pet photos, photos through glass, action shots (kids swinging and dogs running at the park), panoramic shots, etc. and I LOVE THIS CAMERA (sorry for shouting)!  I have tested this camera all over town and I am extremely pleased with the quality of pictures, the speed at which the camera is ready for the next shot and the zoom is fantastic!  I often take shots with no zoom, 20X and 40X just to see the difference between the shots.  I have had very, very few blurry shots even while snapping photos in a moving car.  I will be going back to the lake in a couple of weeks and look forward to more testing.  I probably will not use the touchscreen and GPS features often but they are nice to have in the event they are needed.  I look forward to learning all that this camera can do.  This one is a keeper!!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera. Eats Batteries
Reviews.Author: Remydog
Reviews.Content: There are lots of excellent technical reviews comparing this pocket point and shoot camera to the Canon and other competitive products, so I won't rehash any of that. Just run a Google search on the camera for reviews.My motivation for buying this camera was simple - our family was taking a 2-week trip to China this past August.  I have an excellent Nikon D70, but it's heavy and bulky, especially when hauling the telephoto lens and external flash. I knew we would be on a fast-paced trip in hot, humid weather, so the last thing my family or I wanted was to be burdened by a big SLR and its accessories. Instead, I purchased this small camera and I have absolutely no regrets. In many respects, this was better than my SLR. For one, it takes HD video, which I did a lot. It also has an excellent burst mode, which was very useful when taking photos from a moving tour van since single shots would often be obscured by foreground objects. Using the burst function insured that I had several shots of the same subject from slightly different angles. It also has an abundance of pre-programmed selections, but has several manual overrides for exposure (I wish there was a way to manually focus or set it to infinity). And it fit in my pocket.One problem with the small cameras is they can be a bit hard to hold, stabilize and use due to their size. I solved that problem by bringing with me the Joby Gorrilapod Joby GP1-A1EN GorillaPod Flexible Tripod (Grey and Black). I simply left that attached and used it folded as a hand grip. This proved to be an excellent decision. And a few shots needed the stability of a tripod, so I was all set. Of course, lots of curious onlookers stared at my set up wondering what it was all about.I only have two reservations on this camera. First is the abysmal battery life. Fortunately, I took the advice of other reviewers and purchased two spare batteries and the external charger which were absolutely necessary. On a busy shooting day, I used all three batteries. Second, since there is no viewfinder, it can sometimes be difficult to find your subject and frame the shot, particularly hard to see objects when zoomed fully. Aside from that, no regrets. I highly recommend this camera for daily shots or an important once-in-a-lifetime trip.

Reviews.Title: Very Good Camera!!! Love it!!!
Reviews.Author: K.G
Reviews.Content: The Panasonic Lumix ZS20 14.1 MP High Sensitivity MOS Digital Camera with 20x  Optical Zoom (Silver) is an incredible little camera. It has a ton of features including full manual control and 1080p/60p video in AVCHD Progressive mode and 1080p/30p in mp4.  The pictures are very good and there isn't much need to change from the Intelligent Auto (I.A) mode for most shooting conditions. You also get the ability to store custom settings if you need to. The detail in photos and video is very good, shooting performance is very good with a very fast autofocus system. Macros are beautiful and have rich vibrant colors. The 20x zoom is very good but can be difficult to keep steady whilst shooting video (use a tripod for best results). For still shots, there's some color loss (as expected) at maximum zoom but the photos are still pretty good. The flash is very bright though, so you may not want to use it for very close shots.Overall, it's a very good camera in a small package. I still find it hard to come to terms with the number of features in such a small package.

Reviews.Title: Astounding machine!
Reviews.Author: jim rice "Schmakt"
Reviews.Content: So let's get the low-light thing out of the way... I owned two of the early models of Lumix and was a big fan.  Big enough such that I only gave other brands a cursory glance when looking for another new camera.  The low-light problem has, however, been a problem with these models for a long time. It can be somewhat mitigated with the flash and exposure time, but low-light pictures can still be frustrating.While I was already a fan of the camera despite this one issue, this weekend solidified me as a customer for life.  Less than 24 hours after receiving the camera from Amazon I was on a rooftop bar in Asheville, NC taking wonderful photos of the mountains in the distance.  When the people in front of us moved from their table next to the edge, we moved over to get a better view.  A decision which next lead to me knocking the camera off the side of the balcony.  Five stories up.  I watched the camera twist and fall and finally, with a *thunk* land LCD side down on the roof of the building next door and then slide 30 feet and smash against the side of that roof.  I was sure the camera was gone, but I went down to check on it anyway.  To my complete surprise and delight the only noticeable damage was some very minor scratching on the LCD screen itself.  Even more shocking was that the camera still turned on.  And took pictures.  And video.  And the flash works.  Amazing.The form-factor on this camera is wonderful.  The zoom is fantastic.  The LCD screen is bright and clear, and I'm a fan of the quick-switch b/t taking pictures and viewing. (definitely a complaint I had with my first model)  But, really, if you're looking for a camera that just won't quit, this is it.  Not that I suggest you try drinking on a rooftop and kicking your camera over the side... but if you do, I won't be surprised to hear that it survived.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera!
Reviews.Author: Mark
Reviews.Content: I used to have a DMC-ZS3, but this camera raises the bar.  The quality of the pictures is amazing, especially when you take them with low light.  The video quality is also another thing that is a huge change.  I recommend to buy SD cards that at least are 45 mb/s, you'll see with these ones that the camera save instantly the pictures and videos with zero delay.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix zs20 vs. Canon SX260HS vs. Panasonic ZS15 vs DSLR
Reviews.Author: jn88
Reviews.Content: Panasonic ZS20 is an excellent camera. Autofocus is much better than Cannon SX260. Both have 20x optical zoom. Canon sx260 has issues with hissing noise in the background of all the video I took. I am impressed with the panoramic picture that Panasonic takes. Canon's way of doing panoramic is so slow and difficult because you need to use computer to "stitch" them together. From the review I read, Panasonic ZS15 (lower price)is supposed to have better sensor, therefore better image quality, but comes with 16X optical zoom and no GPS.I would have tried Panasonic ZS15 had I read professional reviews earlier. Overall, I am very happy with this camera. It is supposedly smallest superzoom camera on the planet in 2012.  I was in the market for DSLR. But how often I am going to carry that camera bag around? This Panasonic can easily fit in the pocket, be carried around easily. I decided that a picture captured with my iphone or Panasonic ZS20 is much better than the picture I would have missed totally by taking the time to get DSLR out of the camera bag.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, but fragile
Reviews.Author: Steve Hilton "92109Surfer"
Reviews.Content: I've own about 10 of these things.  They take great photos, except in low light.  But what do you expect from a point and shoot.  The real bummer is that the lens keeps getting jacked up.  My last 3 camera have failed during long trips.  The tele-photo stops working and the lens gets jammed.  I admit I'm rough on the camera, but I alway keep it in a hard case.  It doesn't like sand or dirt.  If you're taking photos around town, no worries.  If you take this thing on a trip around the world, take two…or three.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera!
Reviews.Author: Janneke Bogyo "janb"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera this past summer when my old one began to have an unexplained dark spot on each picture.  I had the Lumix ZS10 previously and really liked it so I decided I'd get the same brand again so that learning to use it would take less time.  I use this particular camera for travel and for taking pictures while I kayak.  For both those kinds of picture-taking, I need a small camera that fits in my shirt pocket and also one with a good long zoom to capture nature photos.  I was thrilled that the zoom on this one is 20X where my older one was a 16X.  That was a great upgrade for me. I also use a long neckstrap instead of the wrist strap that coomes with the camera and this allows me to secure the camera around my neck, then into a shirt pocket while I'm kayaking with less chance of dropping it into the water. The camera takes very good pictures even though I'm often holding it with one hand and sitting in a moving kayak.  I recently took a great picture of a bald eagle in a tree and when I came home, I put the picture on my computer and zoomed and cropped it so that it was a really excellent picture.  I can do this because I do all my picture taking at the highest resolution on the camera.  I don't do a lot of video but when I do, the result is fine for my purposes.While I do own a regular digital SLR camera, I find I use this one much more because of the size and weight limitations of the other camera.  If you're a professional-- or very fussy-- photographer, this may not work for you but for the average picture taking person, this is a great all around camera especially if a high zoom is one of your priorities.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix ZS20
Reviews.Author: Chuckpass
Reviews.Content: I own three Canon "point and shoot" cameras and have used them in a variety of settings over a number of years.  I have  been happy with their performance with a few exceptions:  time to turn on, cycle time when taking a photo and low light photos.  So when it came time replace these cameras I did quite a bit of research on new technology.  My choices came down to a Sony Cyber-Shot DSC-WX150 and the ZS20.  I ended up buying both prior to a trip to Haiti.  I used the Panasonic and my wife used the Sony.  After a month here is what I found:  The Panasonic is a FAST camera.  Time to come on is is very fast. I found I could pull it out and capture I shot quickly, even from a moving vehicle.  Time to focus and cycle time (time to write a photo to the card and be ready for another shot)are also fast (I am using a 32 MB Class 10 45 Mbps card).  And the LCD is clear and bright.  I have had no problems seeing the screen outside in bright light.  My only caution would be to use the lanyard provided.  The camera is so small that hanging on to it while taking photos can be a challenge.  FYI - I was used to hanging on to older cameras that had bulky "handles" containing 3-4 AA batteries.One other thing, the touch screen was very helpful when taking photos from odd angles.  Just tap the screen to shoot.  That took a bit of getting used to as this is my first touch screen camera.  So I took my share of photos of my leg or the ground.  But once I got used to this I found the touch screen handy.  The photos this camera takes are also very good.  It focuses quickly, on faces, movement and does well in low light with no flash.  All in all, a great camera.  I found the camera also does a good job with video.  I used it to take video in a variety of conditions:  outside in bright light, from a a moving vehicle, climbing in the mountains of Haiti and at a concert.  Audio is good for a camera of this size and I found I could zoom in and out while shooting video.  That is something my "prosumer" Nikon DSLR can't do.  I am pleased with the video.On the Sony - it is also a fast camera.  But we found a couple of things we don't like about it.  First, there is no dedicated switch to toggle between taking a photo/video and showing folks the result.  You have to go into the menu to do this.  And downloading photos/video from the Sony to PC is maddening.  The Sony software is not intuitive and we spent considerable time trying to successfully move photos/video.  I did not have this problem with the ZS20.

Reviews.Title: Forgiving and versatile
Reviews.Author: CS
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to take pictures of wiggly grandchildren, nature shots and more mundane images. It replaced a Nikon that could not take a clear picture of a dead bug in daylight. As a point and shoot and mega zoom, this Lumix is the best point and shoot camera I have worked with. It has been equal to the wiggly kid challenge, fast, clear images. Getting good pictures of 11 children, in a group, is special. Running, jumping, ripstick riding kids are a completely different notion. Well done in each instance. I have been shooting, at 20X, birds on the feeder, through the windows, again fast, clear images. When a pheasant looks through your front door, you really point and shoot. Quick adjustments to light conditions. User friendly controls. Small and versatile. Finally, a point and shoot I can recommend.Panasonic Lumix ZS20 14.1 MP High Sensitivity MOS Digital Camera with 20x Optical Zoom (Black)

Reviews.Title: Exceeded expectations
Reviews.Author: OceanHome
Reviews.Content: I was very pleasantly surprised by this camera.  I am a casual photographer with some history in advanced amateur photography, back in the days of 35 mm film and hours spent in the darkroom.  I use photography now to assist me in remembering and savoring life's events, special moments and special people. After pondering whether I should invest in a dSLR, I decided that I wanted a more pocketable, travel-friendly camera that recorded accurately and without undue fuss.  I also wanted a substantial improvement in zoom capability. The point and shoot cameras I had been using (typically in the $150-$200 range) were too prone to yield washed out or skewed color or poor contrast, had inadequate zoom, and seemed to produce satisfying results only when lighting was nearly perfect. I decided to try this one after reading many written and video reviews. (The other cameras I considered were the Canon SX230 and the Nikon Coolpix 9100, but I did not take them home for testing.)It's absolutely amazing. The anti-shake correction is flawless.  Panorama shots are trivially easy and a great way to capture the scenery here in Hawaii. Color rendition is excellent. I was very surprised at the clear nighttime photos I was able to take, handheld and without a flash. Video quality is very good. The autofocus features work very well, and I find myself defaulting to the intelligent autofocus setting for general snapshots.  I like the touchscreen for flipping through photos, but haven't found too much need to use it to pick a focal area. That might change as I experiment further, and it's nice to have the option. The touchscreen is not excessively sensitive, so I have only taken a few photos by accident, by touching the screen unintentionally. The navigation menu is straightforward and it takes only a few seconds to switch to a different pre-programmed mode. I found the sunset, food, panorama, handheld nighttime, and high sensitivity programmed settings very useful. I'd say it took me about 3 hours to get comfortable with the camera, which is very good considering that it is feature-rich. I would recommend this camera to anyone who wants a superior camera for travel and casual photography.

Reviews.Title: Advantage of charging battery inside the camera
Reviews.Author: Adri Lore
Reviews.Content: First of all, the camera takes great pictures and video and deserves five stars.I don't agree with the customers who criticize that the battery is charged inside the camera. I saw one review that gave only two stars just because the USB cable was "too short". Come on, you spend 250 dollars on a camera and then you return it to Amazon and give it a bad rating because of the USB cable?I absolutely love that the battery is charged inside the camera, that makes it perfect for travel. I always carry an external USB battery with me to charge any electronic device from cell phones to mp3 players, and now I can charge my new Panasonic camera the same easy way. For me, that's a great feature, no need to carry around a specific charger.If it's important to you whether the battery is charged inside or outside the camera, you should not talk bad about a great product just because you were too lazy to do some research before ordering.

Reviews.Title: technology and art meet
Reviews.Author: Leonard Frieling
Reviews.Content: This camera for the price is a miracle.  It can fit in your pocket and shoot pictures in the dark. literally, virtually no noise.  Set it to Ai (artificial intelligence I believe).  Turn the flash OFF.  I shot in a large music venue with some hot spots of lights, and generally dark.  In the fringes, it was cave-dark.  The camera sent me a message: "you seem to be taking a hand-held picture in low light with no flash."  The camera then took a burst of 6 shots, combined them internally, and gave me an image that I could easily manipulate in a BASIC photo program.  I'm sure it's an HDR type process.  I changed the exposure and played with some "purpling" to make the color more natural.  Apparently the shutter speed for each of the 6 burst shots, combined with the internal stabilization resulted in an amazing image.  Faces were recognizable in the farthest darkest corner of the room, about 50-60 feet away.  Then, from about 35 feet away, again, no flash, hand-held, and zoomed to capture the head , down to the upper chest, and the microphone and arms.All photographers know that one simply cannot take either of these pictures.  The hand-held zoom in the low light came out fantastic. Excellent exposure, sharp, and printable with no adjustment if that is desired.I have had a number of Lumix/Leica lens cameras, and have had great success with all of them.  On this one, the Ai artificial intelligence setting is truly wonderful.  I've been leaving it there, and just zooming for composition.  this camera, IMO, is so much bang for the buck it is shocking.  Is the image as good as my Sony digital 23 megalixel camera?  No, and you would not expect it to be as good image.  My wife and I are both avid photographers, in my case going back to developing and enlarging in a bathroom in  1964.  I  currently shoot with a Leica Vlux 3, a fully accesorized A850 Sony, and the Lumix pocket camera.  Since it fits in my pocket and does everything (not with the image quality of the Sony of course) I carry it everywhere.  I love this Lumix so much that upon realizing what I had, I got one for my wife]Lenny Frieling

Reviews.Title: AMAZING LITTLE CAMERA
Reviews.Author: norma
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my husband. He has zero patience. It come in the day before vacation.That did not give us any time to study and see how it worked. I  charged it overnight and we leftwith camera and instructions in hand. I  had my Canon camera,  tripod, and  remote flash  and  he had only lumix  zs20 .  Well,  he started  clicking  and reading the  screen.That was  about  all he had to do.  Easy  to  use  and very affordable. Thisamazing  little camera  will take videos also.  Pictures  and videoare  very clear  in  HD.  The pictures  are  better  than  my $1,000.00  canon camera.We love it.you need to use the lumix program  to upload the pictures and videos.  If  you do not you will have problems.it is simple if you follow the steps for the lumix program.  I uploaded my husband's pictures to my canon program and I thought for awhile I had lost the pictures. I  Finally recovered them.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: mrsted
Reviews.Content: This camera is the best in its category.  It is very easy to use, it feels very comfortable in your hand, and most importantly, it takes great pictures.  There is no delay whatsoever, so you can be sure to capture the picture you were hoping to get.  I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a compact, reliable camera.

Reviews.Title: My zs20
Reviews.Author: henry
Reviews.Content: The best camera I have ever baught in my 77years it does the job great and is easy to use ,Lots of fun to use

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera
Reviews.Author: mallarduck
Reviews.Content: Purchased this 20 zoom camera to replace an older Lumix that was about worn out from several years of hard around-the-world use.  This one is just a bit smaller, with lots of new features.  Great travel size.  Best of all, it just fits right in my hand, and the zoom is incredible.  Fast receipt from Amazon, packaged nicely and all arrived perfect.

Reviews.Title: Great zoom
Reviews.Author: Kathleen M Keller
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  The photos are so crisp and clear.  I am really impressed with the 20x zoom.  There are several different settings and the panoramic photo capabilities are very good.  It also has a feature for faces and that works very well.  I think the photo quality with this little camera is better than my expensive Cannon Rebel.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for almost great price
Reviews.Author: Tool Happy
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I loved my last lumix but wanted more manual control (while still having small size and click and shoot). It does all that. I am not pleased however to discover that it evidently requires Lumix batteries because of a software change. My previous camera I had one Lumix and two generic batteries. This new one requires frequent charging and the high $ of Panasonic batteries make back ups less resonable. Plus it requires that you charge from the camera instead of an external charger (again hindering having a ready back up).

Reviews.Title: My ZS20 is a keeper
Reviews.Author: Grumpy
Reviews.Content: First pass test of stills & video, including zooming to 20X meets my expectation...and then some.  After doing a serious review of camera data for several models, I rated this Panasonic unit second to the Canon S100, but the S100 has only a 5X zoom....I needed more.  After a data review determined the top 3, I did a hands on feel, operationonal fuction, and sample photo tests.  The ZS20 won based on a more solid feel, and faster focus.  The other two had a light weight plastic feel.  Ease of operation and picture quality were all close to equal.

Reviews.Title: I really wanted to like this camera....
Reviews.Author: RJ Pawlicki
Reviews.Content: I generally do not leave reviews, but I've been so frustrated with my experience with this camera, I wanted to share some things about it (Esp the Panorama feature) that had not come up when I did my research into this camera.First, the good:-It takes decent pictures, but not great, as long as you have good light.-The GPS is slow, but decent for marking photos.-Impressive zoom.-Amazing video quality (again with enough light).  This is probably one of the most impressive features of this camera, and one of the reasons I had such a hard time determining if I should return it.  Very sharp, and great audio quality (as long as it's not too windy).-I'll also say that the vibration reduction is pretty good as wellNow the bad:-Horrible in low light.  You're going to need a room lit nicely with 60W+ lamps to avoid pixels the size of round tortilla chips.-Horrible User Interface. (Maybe subjective, but I found it anything but intuitive)-Useless touch screen.  It was only responsive when it wanted to be.-The iA mode for pictures is ok, but has a tendency to overexpose and really overexposes when there's a high contrast range.-The 14MP image sensor on this camera is horrible for any zoomed pictures.  My Nikon SLR I expected to have a better senor, but when my 8 year old 7MP Sony DSC-P200 point and shoot takes sharper pictures that can be zoomed into father than this camera, that's a problem.  VERY disappointed by this.-Soft Macro Pictures - to be fair, I didn't experiment much with this before deciding to return it.-Several issues with the Pano feature (my final straw):I've done numerous Panos by taking multiple shots on my Nikon D80 and stitching them together.  While I've had to do some touch up work after the stitch, I've been extremely pleased with my results, and was looking forward to this feature of the ZS20.  On the plus side, the photos are stitched together so that everything lines up, however, you can easily tell in your pictures where the photos were stitched together.  There are faint vertical overlaps / lines / distortions, (not really sure how to explain them) that show up on your panos with this camera.  It does not matter how fast you move the camera as I took some fast, and some REALLY REALLY slowly, and they're still visible.  It's like the camera lined up the photos nicely but didn't blend the colors correctly to create a smooth even image.  The best way I can explain it is if you print a picture on a set of vertical blinds.  It'll look uniform for the most part when each blind is lined up, but you can tell where the separations of each blinds are.The finally, the panos are not 14 MP images stitched together, but some other type of low res pics stitched together.  I took a normal photo at the highest quality setting that was roughly 5MB in size.  A pano of Mt St Helens and the Valley in front of it was less than 1MB.  This was a Decent sized Pano.  Now some of you may say, hey, this a pano, why do you need higher res.  I answer:  DETAIL.  I want to be able to tell if the green thing in the foreground is a tree or a bush, not just a green mystery blob.  It almost looks as if some spots were done with a paint brush.I really honestly wanted to like this camera.  It sounded like it had a great feature set, but if you're going to use the Panorama feature, save yourself some frustration and look elsewhere.At this point, I have no idea of what I'm going to replace it with.  I'm leaning towards a higher end Canon or Sony point and shoot.  I've had very good luck with Sony cameras in the past.On a side note, for those curious, I carry a point and shoot with me for times when I can't get to my D80 fast enough and there's wildlife, or lighting that is moving fast and I don't want to miss the shot.  It's lighter and less expensive than carrying another SLR body/lens combo.

Reviews.Title: Love my new Lumix
Reviews.Author: Pat
Reviews.Content: I have had Panasonic Lumix cameras before and liked them very much. But this one I love. It is finally fast enough to stop most of my action shots, which was very important to me with grandkids who needed to be photographed frequently. Sometimes with animals. It steadies the focus well when zoomed out. And it zooms out A LOT! I got it before my trip to Russia and it performed like a trooper. I did buy two extra batteries and a charger which I couldn't have done without. And a 16GB class 10 memory card. Filled it. Good thing I took an 8 GB class 6 backup card. People make fun of all the pictures I take. Multiples of almost every shot, if possible, because so many were usually blurry. So when I got home with almost 3500 pictures from a twelve day trip I thought it would be like usual and I would be deleting at least half because they were not worth printing. But I've only deleted about 80-100 as unsalvageable. So now I have lots of decisions to make as which ones are keepers. Best of all, it is still small enough to fit into my purse as a permanent accessory.

Reviews.Title: Find a used DMC-ZS3 and buy it instead
Reviews.Author: RikR
Reviews.Content: I have the DMC-ZS3 and have been shooting concerts with it for several years.  I have had consistent great results with the ZS3 in both photos and video.  I have been watching the DMC line over the past year awaiting a favorably reviewed upgrade and thought that the ZS20 was that camera.  I went ahead and got the ZS20 and I have now taken the new camera to three concerts in the past 10 days (Roger Water's The Wall, Alice Cooper, and Iron Maiden).  The photos are almost all blurred and are garbage compared to what the ZS3 created. In fact, the time it takes to actually try and focus is really terrible.  I'd love to have the 20X (40X with digital) that the ZS20 offers, but I'm afraid there is much work to do from Panasonic in getting this camera line to take as good of photos as the ZS3.The video from the ZS20 is good, but not really any better than the ones from my ZS3.I do like a lot of things about this camera (ZS20), but in the end it is a camera that I use mostly for concerts and in that regard it does not do well.  I also shot a bit around the house and outdoors and the photos are much softer and washed out than the photos from my ZS3.  So, I am returning the camera and going back to my trusty ZS3.I will continue to keep an eye on this line of cameras and maybe the ZS25+ or some future camera will measure up to the older ZS3.  I really hope so.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic up in coming!
Reviews.Author: Koiphotography
Reviews.Content: The Lumix ZS20 is a great point and shoot camera. Not bulky, and easy to fit in your pocket. With the 20x Optical zoom it has, you can catch great photos from a distance. A nice 3" TOUCH screen display, allows you to tap and focus on an object. One thing i dont like though, at times it can be slow at focusing on the object. But a feature that I like, that a lot of cameras besides Sony don't have is the Panorama scene. Allows you to take various forms of panorama pictures.I would recommend this camera, Panasonic Lumix is a great model.

Reviews.Title: LCD screen too fragile
Reviews.Author: Bella Bones
Reviews.Content: Hello,  I received this camera as a gift and enjoyed it for about 5 months.  Then the LCD screen cracked. The screen has a screen protector and it was IN the case when this happened.  The crack is not visible on the outside of the screen but clearly it is cracked inside and now is worthless.  I may have to go back to an Olympus camera rather than continuing to put money into a clearly inferior product. One other problem we had was that the camera did not fit well in the case.  It seems like the case we received was for an older model.

Reviews.Title: Best pocket camera for the money, even in 2014
Reviews.Author: Al Abama "Al"
Reviews.Content: I held out for the Canons, hoping that they would get their act together. No such luck and even their latest 2014 model is just a watered down version of their SX280, which takes great pictures but is a zero when it comes to video. This Lumix actually takes slightly better pictures than the newer version - same sensor, more megapixels = more noise.So... the camera. The only huge negative is the proprietary USB cable. Ridiculous. Fortunately this is cured with a batter charger, which is what you want to use anyways and available for not much along with replacement batteries. The camera is built like a tank, well constructed. Some things could be better - Panorama is OK and not nearly as good as it could be but acceptable. This is more than made up by the video, which I'd use in a heartbeat over stitched together warped looking panorama shots.The settings takes some getting used to and the menu system isn't ideal. Could have made some better use of the touch screen but acceptable. There are some mighty fine "how to" videos on this model that work wonders. What I've discovered is that it does point and shoot OK, like many of these cameras, much better in bright light / outdoors. But if you know how to actually use the camera, you can get great shots much of the time, even acceptable low light photography. Night shots were OK and had to retake a few. But again, if you really know how to use the camera, you'll do much better than just point and shoot, which is more than acceptable. You'll have similar issues on all point and shoot models with a small sensor and only a true DSLR will compensate in point and shoot.At this price for the overall value and quality of pictures and features (60p video? crazy), including photos during video, it's an insane bargain. It's the best on the market even at this late date and I'm thrilled with the purchase and have no regrets.

Reviews.Title: Panasonic Lumix
Reviews.Author: Mountainman
Reviews.Content: First off I'm NOT a professional photographer nor do I work for Panasonic or Amazon. I'm a Joe Shmo that enjoys taking pics with simple to use point and shoot cameras. I don't edit any of my pics with Photoshop since my goal as an amateur is to capture the moment exactly as I see it.In 2010 I was in Grand Teton National park and was at a highway overlook which granted me a full view of the 40 mile long Teton range. I took out my Panasonic Lumix 14 mp DH 20 point and shoot started from the left of the mountain range turning, stopping and shooting a series of pics in order to capture the entire range. I think it was about 16 pics total. When I got home I had a professional photo shop in my hometown stitch those pics together to create what turned out to be a photograph 11 inches wide by 8 FEET long. The shop owner said they had never printed anything out like that before and told me that I could not have shot this any better. I give the credit to Panasonic. My Panasonic goes everywhere with me now on my hikes. Fits perfectly in my pocket so I don't have to fumble around trying to find my camera in my pack. Sure hopes this helps those that research before they buy like I do. You will be happy with Panasonic. I assure you! Happy shootin!!!!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Photo and Video - Does not Stand the test of time
Reviews.Author: cjs
Reviews.Content: Because of work, I now own 3 x DMC-ZS19 cameras and 1  DMC-ZS14.  Problems:1.  On three of the camera's, I have developed "black" forms on the photo, looks like something is coming loose internally in the camera.  One a big piece that ended up covering half of the photo, sent it back and repaired, no issue.  The other two are small dots and out of warranty, don't notice until a light colored back ground but then a pain in the back side.2.  The zoom on the latest camera just went out.  It is 4 months old and I will be sending it back in for repair.4.  All four of the cameras either have or have had an issue.The camera takes some of the best photos that I have seen for an amateur - point, click and done.  Using the Sony's or Cannons that I have had, significant percentage of photos were blurred just enough to make you mad.  Video is outstanding as well, as long as you have decent light.  It is a shame that I continue to have issues with longevity of the various parts of the camera.Another upside though, the newer cameras have a built in charger so when you plug into a USB, you charge the camera.  No longer need to pull the battery and put in a charger.

Reviews.Title: great travel camera
Reviews.Author: robert frost "homedoit"
Reviews.Content: I am a semi pro photographer and like this model as it fits in pocket and would not be a tempting "theft magnet" while traveling. I find the low light great, especially sunsets.  My only beef is in the earlier model, it had more scene options to choose from.  for instance, photographing through glass, water, and special effect of slimming.  I have used it for well over two years with zero issues.  batteries hold charge a long time, and I keep a extra one in small carry bag.  I travel for my work 52 weeks a years so cameras can get bounced around so I found that a prescription pill top, (free if you ask nicely from any pharmacy) fits over lens for a perfect "second cover",  I even put some sturdy thread through the side of it and it attaches to my camera strap.  The lens cover that comes with camera opens and closes when turned on/off, but I have seen them damaged in most stores easily by I assume children playing with it.  This is my 5th time buying same ZS models every year or so  and so far have not seen a better lens than these Leicas!  The zoom is very good, with little distortion, another great feature, but of course not as sharp as a larger camera with a specialty zoom lens.  Overall a great travel camera for novice or advanced photographer who does not want lug their normal bigger units. .

Reviews.Title: I LOVE THE LUMIX
Reviews.Author: tdjr50
Reviews.Content: This is my second one. I think Panasonic are the best cameras out there. The quality of the pictures are outstanding! Movies are perfect and the stereo sound is the best. I put it on my wish list and when the price dropped I bought it. This is a very small camera and I recommend you use the wrist strap when using it. The zoom is phenomenal for a small camera. You will not be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: finally..
Reviews.Author: RG CPA
Reviews.Content: Trying to find a point and shoot pocket camera should be easy...  and should take the picture when you push the shutter button.After having a Sony, Nikon Coolpix S9300 ( I almost threw the Nikon out the window ) I purchased this Panasonic after readying many review on this one and other Nikons...I'm so happy!!  I get clear pictures, even in 20x zoom ( I was just trying to see how clear it would be ) and I'm amazed at the photos.it has switches instead of buttons for some of the features and seams (to me) every well made.  Video is good too, but only used it a couple of times..  I'm a father of two active and moving children, and it take clear photos, ever without a flash (but that takes some work).. I recommend this camera.  PS in all fairness, I purchased the Nikon "used, like new" so I recommend buy new what ever you decide..

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: sandee schreiber
Reviews.Content: I actually had the Lumix ZS19 which is without the GPS and I would have preferred that one but couldn't find in my price range. But this is the same camera it just has GPS on it.  It takes great pictures, is lightweight and also has some manual settings on it (which I don't know how to use yet). My previous camera the ZS19 the lens got stuck twice and was going to cost too much to repair.  But I liked the camera so much I bought another.  I actually got the Lumix  ZS25 after that at Costco but the picture quality was just not the same as my other camera.  I found this one here on Amazon and took the other one back.  It has such a great zoom on it, although it scares me that it will get stuck again! But this time I also bought the Canopy extended warranty just in case. Much easier to put in my pocket when I am on my beach walks then having to carry and worrying about a big camera hanging on my neck.  My friends LOVE my pictures and I LOVE my camera!

Reviews.Title: Great value for an ameteur photogropher
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "xacronic"
Reviews.Content: I use this camera mostly for indoor food photography, does the job great! I love the advanced features like touchscreen at this price point!

Reviews.Title: Buying an extra battery for this is a good idea
Reviews.Author: jBj
Reviews.Content: Ordered and received this one day early!First thing I did was read the 197 page advanced manual provided on the included software DVD.That took a while yet provided a lot of great info about the more than plentiful features of this tiny camera.Second thing I did was update the cameras firmware from V1.1 to V1.2 not sure what that did.The support link from Panasonic said something about improved GPS reception and better handheld night shot performance.Third task was to load the map from the disc to the SDXC card I had inserted into the camera.Things I noticed were noisy pictures when viewed at 14.3 megapixels in the photo viewing software that I like to use.Battery time can be very short with GPS on and especially when filming in AVCHD Progressive.The rest of the story for this camera as far as my short time with it is:Stellar performance!The features are many and the pictures if processed and handled with great software are sharp and well balanced.This tiny camera in my opinion is a well put together mix of easy to challenging for the photographer in anyone.I dig the Lumix ZS20 I think it's impossible to pass this up at $161.99.A few goodies that are my favorites:High fps mode (320X240)Handheld night shotShooting thru glass40X zoom with stabilizationiHDRAnd quite a few more presets.About the noisy pics: Just for grins we printed one of the full resolution shots in 5x7 and wowee looks just beautiful!Another tip to help with battery life: I use a 12000 MAH mobile charger pack for my smartphone it will also recharge this camera on the go.I'm not a pro by any means yet definitely a fan of the Panasonics.This will be my fifth Lumix camera owned over the years.I'd say the ZS20 is well made and above all fun to use.Here's to the joys of life through the lens!

Reviews.Title: True pocket camera with 20x zoom
Reviews.Author: Q
Reviews.Content: Two big advantages of this camera. First is that it's tiny, will really fit into a shirt pocket, and light. Second is the 20x zoom. Put those together and you have a very attractive package. Also to be noted is the GPS, which I find useful. It's a fairly easy camera to use, and the picture quality and performance are certainly comparable to other cameras in the same price range. Recommended, especially since the price has dropped to well under $200.

Reviews.Title: best camera so far
Reviews.Author: Dal
Reviews.Content: I've had several point and shoot camera in the past, Vivitar, Olympus, Canon, Sony and three Panasonic Lumix cameras.
